11_usagi: Huh that's a really interesting question. The word fat or curvy, thick, plump, etc etc I'm happy with. I love. I actually enjoy being called them. It's like claiming what I am and they make me feel sexy or cute etc. But I've always took it as a negative to say "glorifying obesity". I think just because I've always heard it in a negative way, where fat has changed in some sense that phrase I've never seen used outside a negative context. So it's actually really nice to ask myself why that is. I think for me obesity itself is a medical term. So while the word obese or obesity never bothered me they felt very medical and dehumanising. The same as if a doctor used only medical terms when discussing something compared to saying it in plain English, I'd feel like a number. So obese makes me feel like a statistic. Whereas fat feels emotional, warm, comforting, sexy.

prosevillarreal: Ok take 2. lol I didn't realize you can't make paragraphs on Twitter. 1. You look fabulous in that dress. 2. I don't like the term glorifying obesity because it just shows the flaws in how society views women. The term was created as a way to diminish fat women who are part of the body positive movement. No other branch of the body positive movement is attacked like the "fat women" section. A thin woman, taking about how she is struggling with the negative views on her real or perceived flaws, and working towards body positivity is applauded. A fat woman finally achieves her goal of being on the cover of a magazine is attacked and labeled as glorifying obesity. Why? Because there can not be anything loveable about fat women, according to our society. I also don't believe in the reclaiming of words, regardless of what derogatory term it is. Reusing the word, is one individual saying they accept the word and that the word can no longer hurt them. But it continues to be damaging to millions of other individuals who haven't found such acceptance. It also fails to prove a point to those who use it negatively, because their brain will never comprehend that the words are used in anything but a negative manner. Furthermore, by trying to reclaim, glorifying obesity, you (general you) keep that term circulating in the vocabulary of society. And it spreads from one person, town, generation to the next. Continuing the cycle of this hurtful and hateful term. I'd rather people say,. The negative use of glorifying obesity, can no longer hurt me because I have come to love and find glory in who I am. (You, we, they, them, are used to mean a general group of people. And are not used to direct my comments at any individual).

mostly10: to me, it seems that it's always used to blame fat people for being anything other than miserable about being fat. unless a fat person is posting about losing weight (not even about health - solely about weight loss), then they're trying to convince others to become, or stay, fat. no one says a peep about thin people "glorifying unhealth" when they post pictures of eating unhealthy foods, or being inactive, or smoking, or drinking, etc. but gods forbid a fat person is smiling. 🙄🙄🙄
pacificmidnorthwesterner: The “o” word still feels so marginalizing to me that I can’t even reclaim it. But I’m so thrilled that you and others are. It took me almost a decade of immersing myself in fat positivity before I could call myself fat without feeling my whole body flush with shame. Now IDGAF, I’m fat and that’s fine! For now, “glorifying obesity” makes me think of Gwyneth Paltrow or Oprah profiting off body hatred or teenage boys and Susan’s and Karen’s on social media getting really mad I’m stealing all their healthcare 🙄 It makes me feel 🤬.
tumtum18: The assumption in this phrase is that no one would want to glorify fatness, hence the medical language of obesity to make it sound like we are celebrating something “unhealthy” as opposed to just delighting in our body diversity. So much is problematic about the assumptions here 1) fat = unhealthy 2) unheaLthy does not deserve glory. I try to glorify my chronically ill disabled fat body as much as possible!
anna_de_rosbourg: Honestly, I don't think that's a thing that really exists most of the time. The people who use it usually mean "I think you're ugly, I hate fat people and I don't want you to be happy in your body because I need confirmation of my disgust". Coming from women, it also often means "You represent what I've been conditioned to hate, steer away from and torture myself not to be. If you can feel beautiful and confident in a body you should hate, then all my efforts, all my torture and starvation are vain and meaningless and then therefore so is my life. So I will bully you and hope you fall back into line and hate yourself and feel ashamed to exist like a good fatty should." The only times I can think of the term actually meaning what it says is when it comes to people fetishising obesity. But, unless they're actual feeders and feedees, these people do very little harm. They just love fat, who cares? (Caveat: they can fetishise fatness as much as they want, almost everybody has fetishes, as long as they don't reduce the object of their desire to just that: an object. As long as they see the person and treat them as such, no harm done. It's the objectification that comes with fetishisation that is a problem.)
sapphrican: i think ppl essentially mean "normalizing fatness" when they say it, but obviously they don't mean it in an empowering way. it's a phrase that automatically makes me roll my eyes because i know ppl mean it in a "being fat is sloppy, gluttonous, and disgusting and you should be ashamed for supporting anyone who would condone such a lifestyle" type way which is bullshit.
ladyt_au: It firstly means, to me, that they either don't know what it is like to be fat in this world or hold shame for having been fat. thecosycottageinn: A fat person bucking the body currency and using their own form of tender! ☺❤
timmywiththebluedresson: You know, I never thought about it too much at first. It always sort of bothered me in a bad-faith-argument kind of way. But as of think about it more, it seems it's always used to further the perception that fat = worst thing ever, and it us always from the "nice people" who are "just concerned for your health!" and I have less and less patience for it. The argument that the agenda to glorify obesity exists implies that people are making fat "cool" in such a way that other people will wish to emulate it and/or not feel the need to "better" themselves by losing weight, and, across the board, that just feels a lot like an "undeserving poor" narrative - a way to force perception that some people - born of human flesh and minds - are inherently not human.
leahrosss: I think it’s usually used when someone is pretending to care about fat people...as if they personally care about our “health”. alannalikebanana: I think for me when I first heard it (saw it in text form) I got hung up on the word obesity as well. I think the world pushes us to be afraid of being “fat” as if you are less of a person because of it. People have compassion for other lifestyles, why are we still fat shaming? Additionally, when I heard the term, the part of me that has narrow mindedness (implemented by years of the “industry” and society) kind of cringed. I immediately went to self care in regards to medical health and joints, diabetes, etc. HOWEVER, being OPEN minded and truly understanding what it *actually* means and how the term is being used, helped me understand its WAYYYY beyond that. withasliceofjess: I've come a long way with this language. I used to believe it was used by the medical community because of all the "risk factors" that come with being overweight.
